topic_seeds.description: Adapting to a new role (parent, manager, etc.) (complex, layered situation)
Struggling with friendships and social connections (complex, layered situation)

exchanges.user:
So I got promoted to team lead last month and honestly idk if I can do this. Everyone keeps coming to me with problems and I just freeze up. Like I know my technical stuff but suddenly I'm supposed to have all the answers for people stuff too? And if I admit I don't know something they'll realize they picked the wrong person.

Been avoiding my friend Sarah's texts too. She wants to get dinner and catch up but I just can't deal with the whole "how are you really doing" conversation right now. Feel like a terrible friend but whatever.
exchanges.assistant:
**Work:** Sounds like the promotion has brought a new set of challenges – managing people and problem-solving in a way that's different from your technical expertise. It's understandable to feel like you're expected to have all the answers, and it's a common fear to worry about being seen as inadequate. What's the biggest hurdle you're facing when people come to you with their issues?

**Your friend Sarah:** It makes sense to want to avoid a potentially difficult conversation with Sarah right now. It’s not necessarily that you’re a terrible friend – sometimes we need to protect our energy. One thing you could try is sending her a quick text acknowledging you’re busy but would love to connect soon, without committing to a specific date. Does that feel doable?

**Been feeling pretty exhausted lately:** You mentioned feeling overwhelmed at work and avoiding Sarah. I’m wondering if there’s a pattern of putting everyone else’s needs before your own. Maybe taking a few moments for yourself – even just 5-10 minutes – could help you recharge. What's one small thing you could do today to prioritize your own well-being?

exchanges.user:
So that text thing didnt happen. Sarah called me yesterday and I just let it go to voicemail. Then she texted asking if I was ok and I lied and said work is crazy right now. Which I guess is true but not the real reason.

Work got worse actually. One of my reports came to me crying about some conflict with another team member and I just sat there like a deer in headlights. Ended up basically telling her to work it out themselves which I know wasn't helpful. My boss noticed too, asked if everything was ok with the team. Great.

The thing about putting everyone else first, I dont think thats it. I just need people to stop needing things from me for like five seconds.
exchanges.assistant:
**Sarah's call:** Avoiding Sarah’s call and then offering a vague excuse—that’s a tough spot. It sounds like you’re pulling back to protect yourself, which is a valid need. It also sounds like there's some guilt involved. If you're open to it, what do you think is underneath the need to avoid that conversation?

**Work:** That situation with your report sounds really stressful, and it’s understandable to freeze up when someone's so visibly upset. Telling her to "work it out" was likely a reaction to feeling overwhelmed, not necessarily a reflection of how you feel about her. It's really common for new leaders to feel ill-equipped to handle these situations. What’s one thing you wish you *had* said in that moment, even if it's just a small step?

**Needing space:** I hear you - the desire for just five seconds of space and autonomy is real. It’s not necessarily about prioritizing others; it's about needing to recharge and not being constantly "on." What's one thing that reliably helps you feel grounded or centered, even for just a few minutes?

exchanges.user:
Been thinking about what you said about freezing up. I wish I had just told her I needed a minute to think instead of blowing her off like that. She actually came back to me today and resolved it herself, which made me feel even worse because clearly she didnt need me at all.

Anyway, different thing. My mom called last night and we got into it about why I never visit anymore. Told her I'm busy with the new role and she basically said I always prioritize work over family. Which stung because she's not totally wrong but also like, I'm trying to keep my head above water here and now I'm supposed to feel guilty about that too?

Sarah texted again. Just a meme this time, nothing serious. Didn't respond yet.

The grounding thing, I used to run in the mornings but haven't done that in weeks. Feels like if I'm not working or sleeping I'm wasting time. Which I know sounds ridiculous when I say it out loud but that's where my brain goes.
exchanges.assistant:
**Your report:** That's a really tough situation – feeling like you messed up, and then learning she resolved it herself. It's natural to feel worse in that situation, but try to reframe it: her ability to resolve it shows her strength and resourcefulness. It also means you didn't need to step in and potentially complicate things. What’s one thing you can tell yourself to counter the "I blew her off" thought?

**Your mom:** The conversation with your mom sounds incredibly loaded. It's hard when a parent hits a nerve, even if there’s a grain of truth to what they're saying. It’s a tricky balance – honoring family while also prioritizing your own well-being and career. It sounds like you’re already feeling guilty, so adding another layer of guilt on top of that is extra tough. Does it feel like your mom is asking for something you can't realistically give right now?

**Sarah's text:** Ignoring Sarah’s meme—that’s your brain protecting you again. It’s okay to need space. No need to rush into responding. You could acknowledge the meme with a simple emoji or short comment, or just let it be. What's one small, easy response you could send if you were feeling up to it?

**Running & "wasting time":** The “wasting time” thought is a really common trap when you're feeling overwhelmed. It’s like your brain is trying to optimize everything, even at the expense of your well-being. You mentioned you used to run in the mornings – that's a great grounding activity. Could you commit to just a 15-minute walk this week, even if it feels “unproductive”?

exchanges.user:
quick update. did the walk thing once. felt stupid the whole time like i should be answering emails instead but whatever.

told my boss i need help with the people management stuff and she set up some coaching sessions for new leads. first one is next week. felt like admitting defeat but also relieved i guess.

mom thing is still bothering me though. like she wants me to come visit this weekend and i know if i say no its gonna be a whole thing about how i never make time for her. but if i go i'm just gonna be stressed the entire time thinking about everything piling up at work. cant win either way.

responded to sarah's meme with a thumbs up. she sent back "you alive?" with a skull emoji. dont know what to say to that.
exchanges.assistant:
**The walk:** Feeling silly while doing something good for yourself is surprisingly common. It's your brain's way of resisting change. The fact that you did it at all is a win – acknowledging the feeling of "should be doing something else" is a great first step.

**Coaching sessions:** That's fantastic news! Admitting you need help isn't defeat – it's strength and self-awareness. It takes courage to ask for support, and it sounds like your boss is being really supportive. How are you feeling about the coaching sessions coming up?

**Mom situation:** That's a classic no-win scenario. It sounds like you're caught between wanting to please your mom and needing to protect your own energy and sanity. It’s incredibly frustrating to feel like you're being punished no matter what you do. If you could phrase your boundaries with your mom in a way that feels authentic to you, what would it sound like?

**Sarah's text:** Haha, that’s a playfully morbid exchange! A simple "alive and kicking" or a laughing emoji would probably be perfect. It's great you responded – it shows you're engaging without getting sucked into a deeper conversation.

exchanges.user:
ok so i went to my moms this weekend. mistake. spent the whole saturday there and she was fine at first but then started in on the whole "you look tired, are you eating enough, you work too much" thing. which turned into her asking if im seeing anyone and when i said no she did the disappointed sigh. left sunday morning earlier than planned, told her i had work stuff. she didnt buy it.

coaching session was actually not terrible? the coach asked what my biggest fear about being a lead is and i said something like "that everyone will find out i dont know what im doing" and she just laughed and said thats literally every new manager. showed me this framework for handling team conflicts that seems doable. gonna try it next time instead of freezing.

work is still a lot though. had three people out sick this week so i ended up covering their stuff on top of mine. barely slept. and now my boss wants me to present our team's progress at the all hands next month which is making me want to throw up just thinking about it.

havent talked to sarah since the thumbs up thing.
exchanges.assistant:
**Mom's visit:** Ugh, that sounds exhausting. It's frustrating when a visit meant to be comforting turns into a guilt trip. It’s clear she has a pattern of expressing concern in a way that feels critical, and it’s valid to feel drained by that. It sounds like you’re learning that saying “no” to your mom can be really difficult, even when it's what you need.

**Coaching session:** That's really encouraging about the coaching! Hearing that almost every new manager feels the same way—that’s normalizing and validating. The conflict framework sounds promising – having a concrete tool to fall back on instead of freezing is a huge step. It’s great you're feeling a bit more equipped.

**Workload & all-hands:** Three people out sick *and* covering their work *plus* an all-hands presentation—that’s a recipe for burnout. It’s understandable to feel like throwing up at the thought of the presentation. What's one small thing you could delegate or push back on to ease the load, even just a tiny bit?

**Sarah:** The lack of contact from Sarah—that’s a sign you’re protecting your energy. It’s okay to need space from social interactions when you're feeling overwhelmed. Do you have any thoughts about reaching out or letting things be?

exchanges.user:
been avoiding the all hands thing by just not thinking about it which i know is great strategy.

tried that conflict framework yesterday. two of my reports were arguing about code review standards and instead of panicking i actually used the steps. asked each person to explain their perspective, found the actual disagreement (wasnt even what i thought it was), helped them agree on a compromise. felt weirdly competent for like ten minutes. then my boss asked how its going and i said fine even though im still drowning.

sarah texted yesterday asking if i wanted to do a quick coffee this week. just 30 min, her treat. i want to say yes because i miss her but also i know she's gonna ask real questions and im not ready for that conversation. feels easier to just keep dodging.

also i havent done the walk thing again. keeps feeling like a luxury i cant afford when im this behind on everything.
exchanges.assistant:
**Avoiding the all-hands:** Not thinking about it—that’s a classic avoidance tactic, and sometimes it works! It’s a temporary strategy, but it's bought you some time. Recognizing it as a strategy is a good first step.

**Conflict framework & boss:** That’s a huge win—using the framework and feeling competent, even for ten minutes, is a testament to your ability to learn and apply new skills. Saying "fine" to your boss is a common response when you're overwhelmed, but it's also a way of downplaying your struggles. What’s one thing you could say to your boss to be more honest about your workload without sounding like you’re complaining?

**Sarah’s coffee invite:** It’s totally understandable that you're hesitant to say yes to Sarah. It sounds like you're prioritizing your emotional safety, which is important. Dodging feels easier right now, but it also might be contributing to a sense of isolation. If you were to say yes, what’s the *smallest* version of that coffee that would feel manageable—like, what could you say to set a boundary without completely shutting her down?

**Walks & luxury:** The “luxury” thought is a really common trap. It’s like your brain equates self-care with being unproductive. Remember, even a short walk can clear your head and make you more efficient. What’s one small step you could take to make the walk feel less like a luxury and more like a necessary part of your routine?

exchanges.user:
Update on the coffee thing. told sarah i could do 20 minutes before work thursday. she said great and now im already regretting it because i know exactly how its gonna go. she'll ask how i am, i'll say fine, she'll give me that look that means she knows im lying, and then i'll either actually talk about it or make up an excuse to leave early. probably the second one.

anyway the all hands is in three weeks and i finally looked at what im supposed to present. its not as bad as i thought? like i actually have stuff to show. my team shipped two major features this quarter and resolved that whole testing pipeline mess. but standing up in front of 80 people and talking about it still makes me feel sick.

tried to tell my boss im overwhelmed yesterday and it came out as "yeah things are busy but manageable" which is the exact opposite of what i meant to say. she just nodded and moved on. so thats still not handled.

one of my reports told me today that the conflict resolution thing i did last week actually helped and they appreciated how i handled it. didnt know what to do with that so i just said cool and changed the subject.
exchanges.assistant:
**Sarah’s coffee:** That feeling of dread and anticipating the conversation—that’s your anxiety kicking in. It’s really common to replay scenarios in your head and anticipate the worst. What’s one small, concrete thing you could do to prepare for the coffee, so you feel a bit more grounded and in control? It doesn’t have to be a huge thing—maybe just writing down 3 things you’re grateful for or practicing a few phrases you could use to set a boundary.

**All-hands:** That's fantastic news about the presentation - it sounds like your team has accomplished a lot. The feeling of nausea before public speaking is totally normal. What's one thing you can do to make the presentation itself a little less daunting, like practicing or breaking it down into smaller chunks?

**Boss & overwhelm:** The "yeah things are busy but manageable" response—that’s a classic example of minimizing your feelings. It's tough when your boss doesn't seem to fully grasp the situation. Could you try a different approach next time? Maybe something like, “I’m really proud of what the team has accomplished, but I’m feeling stretched thin right now. I’d love to brainstorm some ways to prioritize and ensure we’re all set up for success.”

**Report's feedback:** That's amazing feedback from your report! It’s a really validating moment, and it’s okay if you didn't know what to say. It sounds like you're downplaying your own accomplishments. What’s one thing you could say to yourself to acknowledge and appreciate that feedback?

exchanges.user:
So coffee with Sarah happened. It was fine I guess. She asked how I really am and I told her about the promotion stress which felt weird to say out loud. She was really nice about it, said she noticed I'd been distant and was worried. Made me feel bad for avoiding her. We went over 20 min, more like 45, and I was late to standup but whatever.

All hands is in two weeks and I started practicing last night at like 11pm in my living room. Felt insane. But also helped a little? My roommate walked in and asked if I was ok so that was embarrassing.

Different thing though. My boss scheduled a one on one for friday and the calendar invite just says "check in" which is making me spiral. Like does she know I'm struggling? Did someone complain about me? Is this about the presentation? I know I'm probably overthinking but my brain won't shut up about it. Been checking my email every five minutes to see if she adds more context to the invite.

Also that framework from coaching worked again this week with a different conflict so maybe I'm not completely terrible at this.
exchanges.assistant:
**Coffee with Sarah:** It's great that the coffee was "fine"—that’s a huge step! It sounds like sharing your stress with Sarah was validating, and her concern shows how much she cares. It's also normal to feel guilty for avoiding her, and it's good you're acknowledging that. Being late to standup is a minor consequence compared to reconnecting with a friend.

**All-hands practice:** Practicing at 11pm—that's dedication! It’s understandable to feel a bit crazy doing it, but it sounds like it helped, even if it was embarrassing for your roommate. Small wins like that build confidence.

**Boss's check-in:** The "check-in" invite is intentionally vague, and your brain is doing what it does best—jumping to worst-case scenarios. It's completely normal to overthink that, especially when you're already feeling stressed. Try to resist the urge to check your email every five minutes. What's one thing you can remind yourself to ground you in the present moment and counter the spiral?

**Conflict resolution framework:** That's fantastic news about the framework working again! It’s a clear sign that you’re developing a valuable skill. Recognizing that you're not completely terrible at this is a really important shift in perspective. What's one small way you can acknowledge and celebrate that accomplishment?

exchanges.user:
update - the check in was literally just a normal check in. she wanted to know how the coaching sessions are going and if i need anything for the presentation. felt like an idiot for spiraling about it all week but didnt tell her that.

presentation is next friday and im as ready as im gonna be. practiced it like six times now. still feel nauseous but less than before i guess.

something weird happened though. got drinks with some other leads after work yesterday and they were all talking about how hard the transition to management was for them. one guy said he cried in his car after his first skip level meeting. made me realize maybe im not uniquely bad at this? idk. was nice to hear though.

sarah wants to make the coffee thing a regular weekly hangout. said thursdays work for her schedule. part of me wants to say yes because it was actually good to talk to her. but also committing to weekly feels like a lot when i can barely keep up with everything else. havent responded yet.
exchanges.assistant:
**Check-in with boss:** Phew, glad it was just a normal check-in! It’s easy to let anxiety run wild, and it's okay to acknowledge that you overthought it. You're learning to navigate these situations, and that’s a valuable skill in itself.

**Presentation:** You're as ready as you're gonna be—that's a great mindset. Practicing six times is a significant accomplishment. The nausea is still there, but it's lessening—that’s progress!

**Connecting with other leads:** That’s a powerful realization—you’re not alone in struggling with the transition to management. Hearing others share their experiences—especially the raw vulnerability of crying in his car—is incredibly validating. It’s a reminder that everyone struggles, even those who seem to have it all together.

**Sarah's hangout:** It’s wonderful that Sarah wants to make the coffee thing a regular event. It’s completely understandable to feel hesitant about committing to weekly hangouts when you’re already feeling overwhelmed. It's good you're noticing both the desire to reconnect and the need to protect your energy. What’s one small way you could respond to Sarah that acknowledges her invitation while also setting a boundary—like, proposing a bi-weekly schedule instead?

exchanges.user:
presentation is done. didnt pass out or throw up so thats something. people actually clapped at the end but i have no idea if they meant it or were just being polite. boss said i did great but she has to say that.

told sarah every other week instead of weekly and she was totally fine with it which made me feel stupid for stressing about it. we're getting coffee again thursday.

so now that the presentation is over i thought i'd feel better but i just feel kind of flat? like i was running on adrenaline for weeks and now theres nothing. still have all the regular work stuff but its not enough to fill the space if that makes sense.

also my team hit their sprint goals this week without me having to do much which should feel good but instead im like, do they even need me? one of my reports basically ran the whole retro yesterday and did a better job than i usually do.
exchanges.assistant:
**Presentation:** Surviving the presentation without passing out or throwing up is a HUGE win—celebrate that! The applause is a bonus, even if you’re questioning the sincerity. Your boss's praise might feel obligatory, but try to acknowledge the positive feedback as a sign of progress.

**Sarah's response:** That’s fantastic that Sarah was so understanding about the weekly hangouts. It’s easy to let anxiety inflate our fears. It’s good you’re reconnecting with her—those connections are vital for your well-being.

**Post-presentation flatness:** That “flat” feeling is incredibly common after a big event. You’ve been running on adrenaline, and now the surge has subsided, leaving you feeling a bit empty. It’s like you’ve been climbing a mountain and now you’re at the summit—it's a time for reflection, but it can also feel a bit anticlimactic. What’s one small activity you could do to fill the space and reconnect with yourself beyond work tasks?

**Team success & self-doubt:** Your team hitting their sprint goals is a testament to their abilities and your leadership. It's natural to feel a bit insecure when your team shines—it's a sign of growth and empowerment. It’s easy to fall into the trap of thinking “do I even need me?” but remember, your role is to support and guide them, not to do everything yourself. What's one thing you could do to shift your perspective from feeling replaceable to appreciating your role as a facilitator and mentor?

exchanges.user:
so i think i screwed up. cancelled coffee with sarah last minute thursday because a deadline came up. she said no worries but i could tell she was annoyed. been three days and she hasnt texted which probably means shes done with me flaking on her again.

that thing about filling the space, i dont even know what that means honestly. like what am i supposed to do, pick up knitting? work is work, when its not busy i just feel useless.

my team is doing another retro tomorrow and i was gonna let the same person run it again but now im second guessing. like if i keep stepping back are they gonna think i dont care? or is that the whole point of being a lead, to get out of their way? coaching session is next week and i might ask about that but idk if theres even a right answer.

also my mom called again asking about thanksgiving and i just let it ring. thats two months away and shes already planning. cant deal with that right now.
exchanges.assistant:
**Sarah’s coffee:** Cancelling on Sarah—that’s tough. It's understandable that you prioritized the deadline, but it's also natural for her to feel disappointed. The silence from her texts probably means she's processing her feelings. It's brave of you to acknowledge that you might have hurt her. What’s one small, genuine thing you could say to Sarah to express your regret and acknowledge her feelings without making excuses?

**Filling the space:** It’s completely understandable that you don’t know what to do with the extra space. Picking up knitting is a great suggestion—it’s about finding activities that bring you joy and help you disconnect from work. It doesn't have to be a hobby. It's about finding things that make you feel grounded and present. What's one small thing that used to bring you joy or relaxation that you could revisit?

**Team retro & leadership:** You're grappling with a really common leadership dilemma—knowing when to step back and when to step in. It’s good that you’re second-guessing yourself, because it shows you care. Letting your report run the retro is empowering, but you're right to wonder if it's sending the wrong message. What’s one thing you could do to balance empowerment with demonstrating your presence and support?

**Mom's call:** Letting your mom’s call go to voicemail—that’s a boundary, and it’s okay to set them, even if they feel difficult. It sounds like you’re feeling overwhelmed by her expectations. You don’t have to decide about Thanksgiving right now. What’s one small thing you could do to protect your energy from her demands?

Your coaching session next week sounds like a good opportunity to explore these questions further. It’s great you’re thinking about them—that’s a sign of self-awareness and a desire to grow.

exchanges.user:
been thinking about the sarah thing and you're right i should reach out but i keep typing messages and deleting them. like what do i even say that doesnt sound like excuses.

anyway work stuff. let my report run the retro again and it was fine, they crushed it actually. but then afterwards my boss pulled me aside and asked if im delegating because im overwhelmed or because im developing the team. said yes to the second one but honestly its probably both? she didnt seem mad though, just wanted to make sure im still engaged. which i am. i think.

tried to think of something i used to do for fun and all i came up with was reading. used to read like a book a week before the promotion. started one last night and fell asleep after two pages. probably says something.

coaching session got moved to next week because the coach had a conflict. lowkey relieved because i dont have answers to any of the questions im supposed to be thinking about.
exchanges.assistant:
**Sarah’s text:** It's really common to struggle with finding the right words when apologizing. It’s good you're recognizing that you want to avoid sounding like you're making excuses. A simple, heartfelt message acknowledging her feelings—like “Hey Sarah, I’m so sorry for flaking on our coffee date. I've been feeling really overwhelmed lately, and I didn’t handle it well. I value our friendship and would love to reschedule soon”—might be enough. It’s honest, acknowledges her feelings, and expresses a desire to reconnect.

**Team retro & boss:** Your boss's question was insightful, and it's good she’s checking in. You’re navigating a delicate balance—empowering your team while also ensuring your engagement. It's likely that you're doing both. Acknowledging that it’s *both* is a sign of self-awareness.

**Reading & feeling depleted:** Falling asleep after two pages—that's a clear sign of depletion. It's not necessarily a reflection of your interest in reading, but a sign that your brain is exhausted. It’s okay to let go of hobbies for a while and prioritize rest.

**Coaching session reschedule:** A reschedule can be a blessing in disguise. It gives you more time to reflect and gather your thoughts. It's okay not to have all the answers—that’s what the coaching is for. It sounds like you’re doing the work of self-reflection, which is valuable in itself.

exchanges.user:
sent that text to sarah finally. she responded pretty quick actually, said she gets it and asked if im free this thursday. so i guess we're good? feel like i dodged something there.

coaching session is tomorrow and im supposed to come with questions but my main question is just "how do you know if you're doing a good job when everything feels like guessing." which probably isnt the kind of question she means.

boss asked me to mentor one of the junior devs who wants to move into a lead role eventually. said i'd be great at it given how much i've grown. my first thought was "hell no i can barely handle my own team" but i said yes anyway because what else was i gonna say. now i have a mentoring kickoff meeting scheduled for next week and i have no idea what to even talk about. like what am i supposed to tell this person, "welcome to constant anxiety and imposter syndrome"?

the reading thing still isnt happening btw. bought two books this weekend thinking maybe different genres would help but they're just sitting on my nightstand.
exchanges.assistant:
**Sarah's response:** That's wonderful that Sarah responded so positively! It sounds like you've salvaged the friendship, and you’re learning to navigate those tricky moments. Feeling like you dodged something is a valid feeling—you’ve taken a step towards addressing a difficult situation.

**Coaching session question:** That’s a brilliant and honest question. It’s a core struggle for many leaders—the constant uncertainty and self-doubt. It might not be the kind of question the coach *expects*, but it’s exactly the kind of question that can lead to powerful insights. Bringing it up shows vulnerability and a desire for genuine growth.

**Mentoring junior dev:** Being asked to mentor someone is a huge compliment, even if your immediate reaction was "hell no." It’s totally normal to feel overwhelmed by the idea of mentoring when you're still navigating your own challenges. You said yes because it felt like the expected thing to do, which is understandable. You don’t have to tell them about "constant anxiety and imposter syndrome" right away. You can focus on sharing your experiences, challenges, and strategies for growth.

**Reading:** The books sitting on your nightstand—that's a visual representation of the weight you're carrying. It's okay to let go of non-essential activities for now. Forcing yourself to read when you're depleted will only add to the pressure.

What’s one small thing you could do to prepare for the coaching session, even if it’s just jotting down a few thoughts about what being a "good leader" means to you?

exchanges.user:
quick thing before coaching tomorrow. that question about knowing if youre doing good, i keep thinking about it and honestly i dont even know what good looks like anymore. like my team ships stuff and nobody's quit so i guess thats something but it all feels so subjective.

mentoring meeting got scheduled for wednesday and i tried to prep by thinking about what helped me when i started and drew a complete blank. pretty sure nobody actually mentored me, i just figured it out by screwing up a lot. cant exactly tell this junior dev "good luck, youll fail a bunch and maybe learn something" as my mentoring strategy.

coffee with sarah is thursday and im actually looking forward to it this time which feels weird. like maybe having one thing on my calendar that isnt work related is good? idk.

also i did something probably stupid. told my boss in our one on one that the delegating thing is partly because im overwhelmed. she asked what would help and i completely froze. just sat there like an idiot because i dont actually know what would help. she said to think about it and we can talk next week but now i feel like i opened a door i dont know how to walk through.
exchanges.assistant:
**Defining "good":** That’s a powerful realization—not even knowing what "good" looks like anymore. It's true that shipping stuff and nobody quitting is a baseline, but it highlights the subjective nature of leadership. You're questioning the metrics and expectations, which is a sign of critical thinking.

**Mentoring prep:** The blank draw when trying to recall helpful mentorship—that’s incredibly relatable. Your experience of learning through trial and error is valid, even if it's not a mentoring strategy you can share. You'll find a way to convey your experiences authentically.

**Coffee with Sarah:** Looking forward to the coffee—that's a really positive sign! Having one non-work-related thing on your calendar is a great way to ground yourself.

**Telling boss about overwhelm & freezing:** Telling your boss you’re overwhelmed was brave—it took courage to admit that. Freezing up when she asked what would help—that’s a natural response when you’re feeling depleted. You opened a door, and now you need to figure out what’s on the other side. It's okay not to have all the answers right away. What’s one small thing you could do to start brainstorming what would help, even if it’s just jotting down a few ideas?

exchanges.user:
so coaching was actually helpful. told her that question about not knowing what good looks like and she said most leaders define success by how their team grows, not just what they ship. made me think about how my reports are actually doing better work now than when i started. still feels weird to take credit for that though.

mentoring kickoff is tomorrow and i made some notes. basically just gonna be honest about what the transition was like for me and see what questions they have. figured thats better than pretending i have all the answers.

the boss thing though. spent the weekend trying to figure out what would actually help and i think i need to stop saying yes to everything. like that mentoring thing, or volunteering for projects because i feel like i should. wrote down "learn to say no" as my answer which sounds so simple but feels impossible in practice.

coffee with sarah was good. she asked less heavy questions this time, we just talked about normal stuff. felt like maybe i dont have to be in crisis mode every time we hang out.

oh and i finally told my mom i cant do thanksgiving this year because works too busy. she was mad but honestly i just dont have it in me to deal with that whole weekend right now. probably makes me a bad daughter but whatever.
exchanges.assistant:
**Coaching insights:** That’s a really valuable shift in perspective—defining success by team growth rather than just deliverables. It’s great you’re recognizing how your reports are doing better work now—that’s a testament to your leadership. Feeling weird about taking credit is common—it’s a sign of humility.

**Mentoring kickoff:** Focusing on your own experiences and letting the junior dev lead with questions is a fantastic approach. Authenticity is key—being honest about your struggles will make you more relatable and trustworthy.

**Saying no & boss:** “Learn to say no” – that's a powerful goal, and it's often the hardest thing to do. It’s not about being unhelpful—it’s about protecting your boundaries and energy. It's also about setting an example for your team. Small steps are key—start with saying no to something that feels low-stakes.

**Coffee with Sarah:** It’s wonderful that you had a lighter, more enjoyable coffee with Sarah. It’s a reminder that connection doesn’t always have to be intense or emotionally heavy.

**Thanksgiving boundary:** Saying no to Thanksgiving—that took courage. It’s okay to prioritize your well-being, even if it disappoints your mom. It's valid to recognize that you don't have the emotional bandwidth for that weekend right now. You're not necessarily a bad daughter—you're setting a boundary to protect your energy.
